I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   During a Country Programming Mission in March 2006, the Government of Bhutan (the 
Government) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide an additional technical 
assistance  (TA)  grant  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  the  Department  of  Aid  and  Debt 
Management (DADM). A previous grant1 had been approved in 2004. The request reflected the 
Government’s efforts to integrate the analysis of debt sustainability into medium- and long-term 
macroeconomic planning and to promote good governance. The current TA2 was included in 
ADB's 2006 country operations business plan.3
 
2.   The mission visited Bhutan on 6–7 July 2006, and met with senior officials and technical 
staff from the DADM of the Ministry of Finance (MOF). The Government and the mission 
reached an understanding on the objectives, scope, financing plan, and implementation details 
of the TA. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.   One of the main objectives of the Government’s Ninth Five-Year Plan (2002–2007) was 
to  focus  on  good  governance  by  strengthening  public  administration  through  increased 
efficiency, effectiveness, and accountability. In the field of public finances, the Government has 
introduced  a  number  of  measures  to  ensure  effective  resource  management.  It  has 
strengthened the capacity of the DADM by building a strategic and operational framework for 
debt  management,  supported  by  appropriate  information  technology  systems.  Given  the 
country’s growing debt portfolio and a shift to less concessional funding, there is a need to 
strengthen Bhutan’s public debt management. The overall budget deficit grew by about 90% 
during financial year (FY) 2005, increasing the deficit to GDP ratio from 7% to 11%. Growth in 
domestic revenue halved to 14%. Growth in grants was only 13% (compared with 96% in 
FY2004). As per budget estimates, 65% of the overall deficit was financed through domestic 
borrowings and the rest through external borrowings. By the end of FY2005, Bhutan’s external 
debt had grown by 14.7% and amounted to $606.8 million.  
 
4.  Given the scale of the task, additional assistance was needed to support the reform 
agenda.    At  the  Government’s  request,  ADB  responded  with  two  advisory  TA  projects  to 
strengthen Bhutan’s debt management capacity.  The first was approved in July 2002 and 
implemented in the first quarter of 2003,4 while the second was approved in September 2004 
and implemented in the fourth quarter of 2004 (footnote 1).  
 
5.   Under  the  first  of  these  TA  projects,  a  regulatory,  institutional,  and  operational 
assessment of DADM was conducted, in order to build a strategic framework to enable DADM 
to enhance the process of debt management and recording. Modifications to the External 
Resources Management System (ERMS), the original database used by DADM to monitor the 
debt portfolio, were suggested. The ERMS is generated and managed using Excel and Access 
software.  The second TA project built on the findings and outputs of the first by (i) drafting a 
debt policy in accordance with the strategic development plan for the economy; (ii) developing a 
loan  procedures  and  regulations  manual;  (iii) installing  hardware  and  software  for  a  more

6.  Following  the  successful  completion  of  these  two  previous  TAs,  a  follow-up  TA  is 
essential to develop DADM’s debt management capacity fully and to address the financing 
needs of the Government, minimize borrowing costs, keep risks associated with borrowing to an 
acceptable minimum, and provide feedback to policy makers for effective economic planning. 
Training on CS-DRMS under the second TA project was only 5 days and DADM staff are not 
able to use the system. As a result, they are not able to carry out the major aspects of debt 
management, e.g., generation of reports, writing country-specific reports using the system, 
formulation and implementation of a debt and borrowing strategy, management of the existing 
debt portfolio, and provision of guidance on new terms of borrowing based on repayment 
capabilities. DADM needs to be able to monitor all categories of domestic and foreign debt, and 
to analyze the existing debt stock with respect to currency composition, maturity profile, and the 
interest rate structure. Only after the CS-DRMS is operational and DADM's staff are properly 
trained can cost and risk be minimized, guidelines on the appropriate level and terms of new 
borrowings be defined, and timely debt-service repayment be ensured. 
 
7.   The TA will consolidate an audited database on all loans and grants and provide detailed 
training to DADM and RMA staff.  CS-DRMS is more than a computer package. It is a model of 
best practice in debt management that incorporates all the major developments in analyzing and 
managing developing country debt. The installation of the latest version of CS-DRMS should 
enable DADM to manage the country’s debt portfolio effectively by recording, reporting, and 
analyzing a wide range of debt instruments from both economic and financial perspectives. 
Without the current TA project, the newly installed CS-DRMS will continue to be underused and 
the objective of increasing the debt management capacity of DADM will remain unachieved.       
 
8.   The TA is consistent with ADB's country and strategy program (CSP), 2006–2010, for 
Bhutan, which emphasized the need for capacity development in operations as well as in the 
overall management of the development process.  
 
9.   The role of DADM in accounting, auditing, and fund flow management is expanding and 
its accountability as a service provider to line ministries is becoming more clearly defined. 
Effective  management  of  data  on  internal  and  external  public  debt  is  crucial.  This  will 
necessitate  the  compilation  and  processing  of  all  debt-related  data  to  enable  reliable  and 
complete internal and external reporting on debt and related issues. The TA will address that 
need  by  operationalizing  the  debt  management  system  so  it  supports  the  macroeconomic 
objectives and framework of the country.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.   The impact of the advisory TA would be to improve the governance of the Government 
through the specific outcome of strengthened debt management capacity of DADM which would 
facilitate debt analysis for effective macroeconomic planning of Bhutan’s economy. This TA 
project will build on the findings and outputs of previous TAs (footnotes 1 and 4), and further 
develop the debt management capacity of DADM.

3  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.   The TA will support the following activities: (i) an on-site inspection and audit of the 
database to ensure its accuracy; (ii) workshops and user training for staff from the research and 
statistics  divisions  at  DADM  and  RMA  staff  on  debt  recording,  monitoring,  management, 
portfolio review, sustainability analyses, and projections, as well as on country-specific report 
writing; (iii) on-the-job training on how to use the new software to produce analyses and reports 
for  Government  departments  and  international  financial  institutions,  and  (iv)  basic  trouble-
shooting on the daily operation of the new software.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.   The total cost of the TA is estimated at $240,000. The Government has requested ADB 
to finance $200,000 which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The 
Government will finance the balance of $40,000 equivalent through the provision of office and 
workshop space and facilities, counterpart staff, and secretarial support. The detailed cost 
estimates and financing plan are set out in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.   DADM of the MOF will be the executing agency for the TA. The director general of 
DADM will oversee the TA implementation. The TA will be implemented during a 6-month period 
starting in January 2007 and ending in July 2007. One member of staff will be nominated from 
DADM,  and  will  work  closely  with  the  TA  consultant  to  facilitate  timely  and  effective  TA 
implementation. 
 
14.   ADB will engage one international consultant through a consulting firm in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants for a total of 3 person-months. Consultancy 
services will be delivered intermittently. The consulting firm will be engaged through single 
source selection5 to ensure prompt provision of consultancy services. Single source selection is 
appropriate in this case for the following reasons: (i) the consulting firm is clearly more qualified 
than any other for the assignment since the firm successfully completed an earlier part of the 
work, i.e. CSDRMS installation and provision of data entry training to DADM under TA 4398; (ii) 
the requirements of the proposed TA (i.e. operationalization of CSDRMS) represents a natural 
continuation of previous work carried out by the consulting firm; and (iii) the consulting firm has 
unique  qualifications  by  being  the  sole  distributor  for  CS-DRMS  in  non-Commonwealth 
countries. The consulting firm will provide a consultant who is a debt management software 
specialist. The consultant will review the recommendations of the previous TA with a view to 
translating them into the operationalization of CS-DRMS 2000+ software package for staff from 
DADM as well as for staff from RMA’s research and statistics division. The outline terms of 
reference are in Appendix 3. 
 
15.   The consultant will prepare (i) an inception report within 15 days of fielding, which will 
include a needs-based assessment and an action plan; (ii) a midterm report submitted 2.5 
months after fielding; (iii) a draft final report submitted 2 weeks before the end of the assignment; 
and (iv) a final report at the end of the assignment. All reports will be submitted (in hard and soft 
copies) to both DADM and ADB for review and comments. The consultant will incorporate the 
comments  received  from  DADM  and  ADB  before  finalizing  the  reports.  The  findings  and

recommendations of the inception report and the draft final report will be discussed during 
tripartite meetings. 
 
16.  Overseas training will be conducted at the Crown Agents training center in London, UK. 
Crown Agents is the sole distributor for CS-DRMS in non-Commonwealth countries such as 
Bhutan. Overseas training will allow for advanced CS-DRMS training courses for DADM officers 
including ‘New Challenges in Debt Management for Loan Departments’, ‘Debt Restructuring 
Techniques’,  and  ‘Effective  Domestic  Debt  Management’.  The  overseas  training  will  be 
procured according to ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. Crown Agents will be directly contracted 
because it is the sole distributor for CS-DRMS in non-Commonwealth countries. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
17.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance, not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000, on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Bhutan  for  Capacity  Building  of  the  Department  of  Aid  and  Debt 
Management’s Debt Management Unit, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANT 
 
1.   The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  provide  for  3  person-months  of  consulting  services 
carried out by one international consultant. The consultant will undertake all tasks outlined in the 
terms of reference, as well as any related tasks that may be required to achieve the objectives of 
the TA. 
 
A.  Debt Management Software Specialist (3 person-months intermittent)  
 
2.   The consultant will be a public debt management software specialist who has had at least 5 
years  of  experience  with  major  debt  management  software  packages,  e.g.,  CS-DRMS  of 
Commonwealth Secretariat, the Debt Management Financial and Analysis System (DMFAS) of the 
United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), the Debt Sustainability Model 
(DSM+) of World Bank, and private packages such as Debt-Pro. The consultant will work closely 
with Department of Aid and Debt Management (DADM) staff to achieve user optimization of the 
CS-DRMS 2000+ software package. The consultant’s responsibilities will include the following:  
 
(i)  oversee the loan database migration of the new debt management system (CS-
DRMS 2000+), and ensure data validation; 
 
(ii)  review data input and complete an audit of the CS-DRMS 2000+ database; 
 
(iii)  review data capture arrangements in the CS-DRMS 2000+ system to ensure that all 
transaction data are captured accurately and explain to DADM staff the range of 
system-generated reports that CS-DRMS 2000+ can produce; 
 
(iv)  organize, design, and conduct user training seminars and workshops on public debt 
management  for  DADM  and  Royal  Monetary  Authority  (RMA)  staff  from  the 
research and statistics divisions, focusing on system and user optimization of the 
CS-DRMS 2000+ software package as well as on the use of management tools in 
CS-DRMS 2000+, in particular (a) database maintenance, (b) debt recording, (c) 
debt monitoring, (d) country-specific report writing, (e) disbursements and projects, 
(f) financial simulation, (g) forecasting under alternative borrowing options, and (h) 
debt portfolio management and review; 
 
(v)  provide on-the-job training to DADM and RMA staff from the research and statistics 
divisions  to  ensure  the  sustainability  of  effective  debt  management,  to  include 
financial and debt sustainability analyses based on data generated by the CS-
DRMS 2000+ software; 
 
(vi)  provide on-the-job training to staff from research and statistics divisions of DADM 
and RMA on (a) how to use the new software to produce analyses and reports on 
debt  and  related  topics  required  by  government  departments  and  international 
financial  institutions,  and  (b)  trouble-shooting  in  the  daily  operation  of  the  new 
software; and  
 
(vii)  prepare an inception report that includes a needs-based assessment and action 
plan, a midterm report, a draft final TA report, and a final TA report based on the 
findings from (i) to (vi), and on feedback from DADM and the Asian Development 
Bank.
